thread.title: Ireland’s Brexit hit list: Dublin to outline demands as Taioseach meets EU chief Juncker
thread.title_full: Ireland’s Brexit hit list: Dublin to outline demands as Taioseach meets EU chief Juncker

title: Ireland’s Brexit hit list: Dublin to outline demands as Taioseach meets EU chief Juncker
text:
Ireland’s Brexit hit list: Dublin to outline demands as Taioseach meets EU chief Juncker Ireland’s Brexit hit list: Dublin to outline demands as Taioseach meets EU chief Juncker IRELAND was today set to deliver its demands to Brussels over Brexit as Taioseach Enda Kenny flew into town to meet with EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker. PUBLISHED: 13:15, Thu, Feb 23, 2017 | UPDATED: 13:33, Thu, Feb 23, 2017 GETTY Enda Kenny was in Brussels today to meet Jean-Claude Juncker 
Dublin was expected to make Britain’s pending exit from the bloc its top priority as Mr Kenny held a series of crunch meetings with business leaders and politicians. 
This morning he met with the Belgian prime minister Charles Michel to lay out Ireland’s concerns over Brexit, which include maintaining its most important trade relationship and keeping the internal border with the North open. Related articles Gerry Adams predicts return of hard border splitting Ireland 
He then assented a high-live business event in Brussels, organised by the Irish embassy, at which the commercial implications of the UK quitting the bloc were set to be the dominant theme. 
Theresa May has attempted to woo Irish leaders over Brexit and Whitehall as seen Dublin as a potentially critical ally in ensuring that a sensible exit deal is struck. GETTY Dublin's chief was expected to lay out his Brexit negotiating demands GETTY The Irish Taioseach also met Belgian PM Charles Michel 
But equally Ireland has made clear that it is totally committed to its EU membership, with foreign minister Charles Flanagan insisting his country was “on the side” of the other 27 members for the talks. 
Finally Mr Kenny will meet with EU Commission president Mr Juncker at the Berlaymont building in Brussels this afternoon, with a press conference scheduled for after the talks. 
He was likely to bring up the possibility of a future trade deal with Britain which will be a top priority for Ireland, as well as ways to avoid the reimposition of internal border checks. 
According to Observatory of Economic Complexity (OEC) figures the UK is Ireland’s second largest export market behind only the US, with Irish businesses selling us £15.4 billion in goods and services every year. 
The country is also heavily reliant on Britain for incoming goods importing a third of everything it needs from the UK every year, to the tune of £19.5 billion. 
Up to a million people cross the border between Northern and the Republic of Ireland every day, many for work, and it is feared that imposing checks and restrictions would have a devastating effect on local economies. 
More to follow.
